entry.title: father of French fighter aircraft (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the "father of French fighter aircraft" (pictured) became interested in flying whilst suspended from the French Army following a court-martial?

entry.title: Use This Gospel (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that the remix of Kanye West's "Use This Gospel" was added to DJ Khaled's God Did at the last minute?

entry.title: Venu Chitale (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that BBC radio broadcaster Venu Chitale taught listeners how to cook without meat when it was rationed during the Second World War?

entry.title: Ball Ground, Georgia (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Ball Ground, Georgia, received its name because the land was originally used by Native Americans to play stickball?

entry.title: On Guard for Peace (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Sergei Prokofiev's oratorio On Guard for Peace has been called "Kremlin music" and "Stalinist era kitsch at its most egregious"?

entry.title: Leon Burton (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that Leon Burton set the NCAA record of 9.6 yards per carry in 1957?

entry.title: How We Do (Party) (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a copyright infringement suit was filed against the song "How We Do (Party)" for its use of the phrase "party and bullshit"?

entry.title: a Florida TV station (Wikipedia — did you know?)
entry.content: ... that a Florida TV station operated from an abandoned amusement park?
